text: I stare at the bend in the staircase for two seconds, then finally look away.
Chasing after her would probably earn me nothing but more humiliation.
I slide the door bolt back into place and take a deep breath, finishing what needs to be done in the tavern—as if nothing happened.
“...Just stay alive.” I murmur to myself.
The words sound like self-mockery, or maybe a habit polished smooth through repetition.
I pull the medicine kit from beneath the counter and press an alcohol pad against the cut at the corner of my mouth.
The sting shoots into my skull like a needle, and I suck in a sharp breath.
I grit my teeth and wrap the bandage twice, tying it tight. When I look up again, the reflection in the glass looks like a battered stranger.
A few copper coins from the drunk still sit on the counter, one of them having bounced into a crack in the wood with a faint clink.
I don’t pick them up yet. First I set the kicked-over chair upright, wipe away the spilled ale, and sweep the snow outside the door.
The customers finally dare to move, paying in hushed voices before slipping out. Their footsteps are lighter than usual, as if afraid of disturbing the person upstairs.
I press the lid back onto the ale barrel, check the latch, and make sure the short sword is still within reach beneath the counter.
—If he comes back, at least I won’t just stand there and take the beating like before.
Only after all that do I finally sit down.
My knuckles are still numb, the corner of my mouth still throbbing faintly. But something else feels worse:
She was too familiar. Familiar as if she had lived here a long time—familiar enough to know where the key was hidden without asking.
My gaze drifts to the brass die on the counter.
It lies there quietly, its edges catching the firelight with a cold gleam.
I hadn’t touched it. Yet it seems to have been nudged by something unseen, rolling half a turn on its own—
“Thud.”
A faint sound of a door closing comes from upstairs. Then silence again.
A strange intuition creeps over me: this isn’t her first time staying in that room, and it isn’t her first time walking up those stairs on a morning like this.
And me—maybe this isn’t the first time I’ve endured the pain and cleaned up the tavern as if nothing had happened.
